title: 108_hr1197
content: The Act titled "Product Safety Notification and Recall Effectiveness Act of 2003" is established for the purpose of improving product safety notifications and recalls. The Consumer Product Safety Commission conducts around 300 recalls of hazardous consumer products annually. They heavily rely on media and retailers to inform consumers about unsafe products due to limited contact information from manufacturers. Only about 7% of consumer products have known consumer contact information. The Consumer Product Safety Commission emphasizes the importance of direct consumer contact for product recalls. Companies with consumer purchase data can effectively notify consumers of recalls. The Consumer Product Safety Commission emphasizes the importance of direct consumer contact for product recalls. Simplified owner cards accompanying products have been successful in increasing recall compliance rates. The purpose of this Act is to improve recall effectiveness and reduce deaths and injuries from defective consumer products. The Act aims to enhance recall effectiveness by requiring manufacturers to include product safety owner cards or develop electronic registration for certain consumer products. It also encourages creativity in notifying consumers about product recalls. The Act aims to enhance recall effectiveness by requiring manufacturers to include product safety owner cards or develop electronic registration for certain consumer products. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines terms from the Consumer Product Safety Act and specifies that a "covered consumer product" includes juvenile products, small household appliances, and other products deemed appropriate by the Commission. Juvenile products are durable items intended for children under 5 years old, such as cribs. The Act defines terms from the Consumer Product Safety Act and specifies that a "covered consumer product" includes juvenile products like cribs, high chairs, strollers, and children's toys. The term "product safety owner card" refers to a standardized product identification card supplied with a consumer product by the manufacturer. A "small household appliance" is a consumer product like a toaster, blender, or coffee maker. The manufacturer can provide a product safety owner card to collect minimal personal information for recall purposes. Consumer products safety standard requires a system to provide notice of recalls for certain products. The Commission must establish a consumer products safety standard that mandates manufacturers to have a system for notifying consumers of recalls. This system must include product safety owner cards, Internet registration, or other specified methods to create a database for recall notifications. Alternative methods may involve online product registration. The standard for consumer product recalls may involve online registration, consumer notification systems, electronic tagging, and other strategies to increase recall effectiveness. The Commission must issue a proposed standard within 90 days of enactment and finalize it promptly. The Commission must issue a final standard for consumer product recalls within 270 days of the enactment of the Act.
